commentBody: No comment on the crossword but maybe the word to describe how the puzzle is made is ‚Äòelan‚Äô

Many commenters thought that last Tuesday‚Äôs puzzle was tougher than the average Tuesday. I think we may see some of the same again this week. 

My time, though not off by more than a couple of minutes, was definitely not a Tuesday time.

Maybe I'm just more awake at night, but this one seemed breezy to me.

Fun to read that Lance's children got in on the brainstorming of the themers. Does that make them STORMCHASERs?

I shot myself in the foot right from 1A. I figured "5 letters? Must be fault." That started me on the road to disaster.
When the crosses didn't fit I had to just wipe out the northwest corner and start over. Fun grid overall though. Nicely contrived!
Perfect Tuesday, and I certainly can‚Äôt be upset with a Harry Potter theme. Although I‚Äôm waiting for the JK Rowland haters to come out in force.
Great puzzle, Lance!  Loved the description of this puzzle as ‚Äúbrough.‚Äù  Thanks for the new word, Sam!

And the category is: The Federalist Papers. Wait, wait, I'm sorry, that's my bad. That's for regular "Jeopardy", which we'll be taping later today. Your category is: Horsies. All you have to do is tell me "Are Horsies pretty?"

Yes or no, we'll except either answer. "Are Horsies pretty?". 

Keep in mind, there's no wrong answer.

Was going a bit slowly until I got to the Harry Potter clue, and fortunately I remember enough HP lore that those long crosses immediately came together after that. Ended up just slightly under my average Tues time. Perfect (and definitely breezy) for a Tuesday, imo.
Quidditch easy, world beaters still not sure a word or phrase. Faster than my average Tuesday which was nice. Felt easier than yesterday.

Seems 60A is a stretch: flyer the much more common spelling for handbill vs. flier.  Could have clued "flier" many other ways, or used the well known singer Mya as clue for the down, leaving "handbill" in place as the clue for "flyer".

I'm not into Harry Potter so I was quite surprised to get the theme - or rather the revealer, as the themed answers I simply solved from their individual clues. There also seemed to be quite a lot of trivia for Tuesday, but I knew most of it - also rather unexpectedly. My wife and I visited the Craters of the Moon in 2013 on our way from Oregon to the Tetons so it was a gimme üôÇ
It is news to me that baby goats can only pronounce M‚Äôs and don‚Äôt develop the ability to form the B sound until the third year.

A crisp little Tuesday. I skipped the Northwest and came back to it last, at which point the theme helped me with KEEPER being the only remaining QUIDDITCH position I could think of. 

Rebuilding after Saturday‚Äôs drubbing. 

Thanks for the great puzzle, Lance Enfinger.
Great puzzle! 10 points to Lance Enfinger!!
1 Across is terrible cluing. A lines judge never says "in" or "its in." The only words they ever say are "out" "fault" or "foot fault"

WHAT A TREAT to have such an artful dodger of a puzzle on a Tuesday.  I was ready to strangle my laptop when "key" absolutely refused to be the lock locker, then when I TOOK A Stab AT 23D, I was stymied once again.  The fills were so fresh (even the OREO had a little crunch left in it) that the whole puzzle was fun, start to finish.

What a delightful family you must have, Mr. Enfinger, and good for you that you are showing them the joy of word work.  Thank you for this one.

Enjoyable! My time was longer because I kept dozing off. I also got stuck on WORLDBEATER (üôÑüôÑüôÑ) and MAA (again). I guess my children are still *kids* because I hear MAA all the time.  Would that make me the G.O.A.T.? (insert groan here). Hey, ITOOKASHOTAT it!

Crossword puzzles always have at least one eerie clue. Today‚Äôs ‚Äúweird to see that‚Äù is DRANO. We have a clogged kitchen sink that we just can‚Äôt clear. The Liquid Plumber equivalents here in Portugal are not working. Hubby took apart pipes, and even used the snake (or ‚Äúcobra‚Äù in Portuguese üêç). It‚Äôs still backing up. I‚Äôm guessing one more week until he calls a plumber to finally GETITDONE.

Bom dia

ESPRIT
noun
es¬∑‚Äãprit i-Ààsprƒì 
Synonym of esprit:  vivacious cleverness or wit

Alex, I‚Äôll take Harry Potter for $1000 - What is Gryffindor? Perfect Tuesday and I was definitely on the same wavelength as Lance. I did one pass of across clues and had it mostly filled in with only a few downs to finish it. 
Thank you, Lance for this perfect pick me up. ü¶â
What a lovely lovely puzzle. Thanks Lance!

I lovely workout, although I missed the theme altogether.  

I adored the ALEXTREBEK clue/answer.

"She was afraid to come out of the water.
She was so nervous someone would see...."

Thanks for a fun flashback and a silly song bouncing 
around in my head. 
Thanks for the puzzle and the smile and the memories.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll take 30D for $100‚Äù
Board reveals CANADA
*buzzer*
‚ÄúWhat is Birthplace of Alex Trebek‚Äù
That‚Äôs correct for the win! 
(And a lot of other really great people)
Lovely, quick, fun!! Rare elegant 'Harry Potter-themed' anything. WHAT A TREAT was my favourite :)
I‚Äôd say ‚Äòhead off‚Äô and never ‚Äòhead out‚Äô. That‚Äôs the thing with idiomatic English - it changes by the mile.

Cricky (clever + tricky)? Frunchy (fun + crunchy)? Whatever you all it, call it a good Tuesday. I confess that the theme never occurred to me, even though I got QUIDDITCH easily. But the fact that the theme wasn‚Äôt needed, just there for potential support, is part of what makes it a good Tuesday puzzle (IMO). And I will never stop admiring the amazing fictional world of the Harry Potter series, no matter what I may think of its creator. Sometimes, art overcomes its origins.

I spent several minutes poring over a completed puzzle wondering where I‚Äôd gone wrong only to discover that FLIER, the less-common spelling of ‚Äúflyer‚Äù, was to blame. The cross-clue was not helpful for me to distinguish between the two, as sports trivia is far from my forte‚Äîand ‚ÄúMya‚Äù and ‚ÄúMia‚Äù are both valid names.

Not commenting to protest the puzzle or anything; just here to gripe a bit!

Strands Thread.  Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #317
‚ÄúBundle up‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ


Smoothiest one yet. 

"Baby it's cold outside . . . "
Tried to guess the reveal with zero result.  Nice puzzle and learning the kids role in the creation is icing on the cake.

Glad to see my chewy solve experience was shared by most. Tuesdays do seem to be getting tougher.

As an HP obsessed family QUIDDITCH and its associated positions was a total gimme, appreciated all the more as so much of the surrounding fill was a head scratcher.
I do have an issue with 1A (I see I‚Äôm not alone). In over 50 years of watching Wimbledon, not once have I ever heard ITS IN by a line judge. Just no.
The Jeopardy presenter needed the crosses to complete the surname. ALEX I remembered, the rest I did not, never having seen the programme. 
Love the misdirect for GEL.

I can‚Äôt think of a better term for this than bracing; like a walk on the beach in a Force niner. A lovely feeling of achievement once it‚Äôs over.
HP? There was nothing about Hewlett or Packard in this puzzle...

The Harry Potter connection went right over my head.  The name of the game was vaguely familiar, but I just assumed it was a kid's (MAA) game I was unfamiliar with. 

I was surprised to see that ATTENTION SEEKER, STORM CHASER and TOOK A SHOT AT were debuts.  All three are so much in the language.

Interesting Tuesday solve. I'm not at all familiar with QUIDDITCH, so that and all the other theme answers had to be worked out from the crosses. And still managed to come in right around my average Tuesday time. First puzzle find today was kind of interesting. A Tuesday from April 5, 2005 by Harvey Estes. The first three theme answers were straightforwardly clued. Those answers: 20a. THISINSTANT 27a. THATGOODNIGHT 50a. THEOTHERWOMAN And then the 'reveal' clue and answer: "Hint to the starts of 20-, 27- and 50-Across" ODDSANDENDS Here's the Xword link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/5/2005&g=29&d=D Might put another puzzle find in a reply. ...

Given that "goal" is spelled in English. 'Ol√©' would typically be used after a each successful pass in a long string of possession, normally while your preferred team is ahead and just trying to run down the clock. And not after a goal.
Alex Trebek didn‚Äôt ask questions. He provided answers. The contestants had to create the appropriate questions.

GEL was a great one.

HP hit the bittersweet space in time
when my boys were voracious readers,
but had *just* grown out of wanting me to
read to them as they snuggled in bed.

Ronald Dahl, The Black Stallion, Ramona the Brave‚Ä¶
I loved those cozy evenings so very much.

Nicely done, Lance and Rylan!

The Harry Potter theme today warmed my little nerd heart ‚ù§Ô∏è 

This was a lot of fun, and felt perfectly Tuesdayish.

Thought for the day....
If we destroyed all the art, literature, or music whose creators had questionable actions, thoughts, or comments, we would hardly have any culture left to speak of.
I had Tims instead of Toms and was struggling as to why there was a rude word in 26D
Decent enough, but did the cow eat the sheep?

Yeah, I vacuum behind the couch alt-weekly‚Ä¶ a.k.a. every six months or so. (Don‚Äôt tell any one.)

Smooth puzzle. Loved the very niche botanical theme: witch‚Äôs broom, which (true story) has always been a fascination of mine.
If you‚Äôre looking for TOMS, you can‚Äôt do much better than Hardy and Petty!

Oh, I the gyrations I went through trying to suss the revealer after leaving it blank and not looking at its clue, just the kind of gyrations my brain hungers for.  I got nowhere, nor would I have come any closer had I permutated through infinity, because I know nothing of QUIDDICH besides its name.  No matter.  It was brainstorm heaven.

Lance Enfinger has range, following his debut Saturday ‚Äì a puzzle about which I waxed rhapsodic, even for me! ‚Äì with an early-week offering.  I found a lot to like today as well:
‚Ä¢	That FLAKE fallen to the ground, with a neighboring BRR.
‚Ä¢	Three very worthy debut answers (and debut answers aren‚Äôt automatically worthy) ‚Äì ATTENTION SEEKER, TOOK A SHOT AT, and STORM CHASER.
‚Ä¢	A lovely TIL in SIT SKI.
‚Ä¢	The SAT down and backward LEG up.
‚Ä¢	A magnificent abutting PuzzPair¬© of KIM CHI and IT‚ÄôS HOT.
‚Ä¢	The answer that touched this Jeopardy addict‚Äôs heart. 

All in all, a splendid outing, Lance, once again.  Thank you so much for making this!

This puzzle wasn‚Äôt a HIT for me. Much of it felt uninspired and the cluing was a bit clunky. I think the main issue is my own fault: I dislike Harry Potter. As a musician, it made me cringe to see it spelled as FLIER. I‚Äôve never seen it spelled that way. Surely there was a better way to clue that word.

Misdirection to the max; it had me going around in circles!
Such a puzzlement!
Nice!

Nice Tuesday puzzle, with a solid theme (if you've spent anytime in the Potterverse, that is).

Found QUIDDITCH crossing KIMCHI especially appealing, for some reason I still can't explain.

Having just filled in ERSE at 27D, I read "28D Back end" and desperately hoped it would be "ARSE".

"Labor day event" for BIRTH was very cute. Briefly missed the uncapitalized "d", and wondered if BARBQ was about to appear.

LOL on some of the top comments today, geez folks. Just came to say that I find these early week puzzles to truly be an art form. It has that same feel of impossibility at certain points of a late week puzzle (SE got me until the cabbage popped into my head [GET IT? Cabbage? Head?? Hello?!?) but it comes together SO much easier. To me that is art.
38D is a very timely clue - today is the 125th anniversary of thr opera‚Äôs debut in Rome

What is it with OREO in these crosswords? How much are they paying for this weird advertising?! I found that back in 2022 it was noted that it was a crazily common word: https://nytimes.com/2022/08/14/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2022-08-15.html I searched for "NYT crossword oreo" and the top question Google showed me was "Why is Oreo always in the nyt crossword?" Is it a rite of passage for the crossword setters?
Everything I know about Harry Potter I learned from the NY Times crossword.  So as you can imagine, I've learned a lot.

I never read a Harry Potter book or saw a movie. I've heard the word QUIDDITCH, thought it might be a sport, but know nothing about it. Nevertheless, I managed to complete this puzzle without any lookups. This despite eight sports clues, including the revealer.

Not surprised that most of the comments are love fests, since they usually are. For me, this ranks as one of my most hated puzzzles ever. If that's strong language, well, that's the way I feel about it.
I dunno about 17A. Seems to me that, if it becomes a sting operation, that means the beekeeper has done an extremely poor job.

Dear oh dear, I went soaring over my average today. I couldn't get started in the NW at all, 10+ minutes down the drain as everything I thought of seemed to clash with everything else. I gave up and sulked down to the SE corner, whence I managed to fill up to completion without too many problems, but no music :(
Turns out I'd convinced myself that an hRT TEST was perfect, with AHhS crossing. Another 10+ minutes at least finding that.
Hope others had a better day!

It's a brisk negative 7 outside today. (Feels like minus 25!) BRR.

Thankfully, this puzzle warmed me right up. Lots of fun entries, like BEEKEEPER, HOAX, TEENIE, BAMBI. WHAT A TREAT!

A Harry Potter themed puzzle?  Really?

Considering that Daniel Radcliffe is over 35 years old, this hardly seems timely.  

The "Crossword Stumper" featured today was on the word "Calvinball".  That seemed appropriate, in that both Calvinball and QUIDDITCH are both imaginary games, fictional relics of another era.

Personally, I prefer Calvinball.
I do appreciate all the clever clues to OREO(S), but I also wish we could have at least a temporary moratorium on the word.

Right off the bat -- the 1A clue baffled this tennis player of some 40  years, 

A line judge doesn't call a ball in during a point, they make a hand gesture (palms down) so as not to disrupt the play. Thus, if asked after the point by the chair umpire, they would instead say "it WAS in".  

So many other ways for this to be clued, using tennis shows a lack of understanding of the professional game.

[Forgetting to plug the computer in, say]



I.T. SIN


I felt like I was playing Connections, staring at Keeper, Beater, Seeker and Chaser, knowing that they are the final set but not knowing why and not wanting to submit them until I figured it out. Alternate reindeer maybe? Finally had to solve the revealer. Oh well.


I think there should have been a note with this puzzle, "The Harry Potter books are must reads before solving" so that we would know it was mandatory and not just a recommendation.
Cute puzzle
I‚Äôm taking issue with flier vs. flyer, but a fun one to solve, all the same.

I guess it was inevitable that Harry Potter would take over the crosswords, too.... WORLD Domination!

I TOOK A STAB AT 26D before getting SHOT...  

You don't see ALEC? TREBEC?'s name spelled out that often, do you?  Easily corrected.

Lance Enfinger....sounds painful!  I ran my finger up on a very sharp pin yesterday; ow, ow, OW!
Quilting can be dangerous to your health!

Yes, it's hard to ignore the author's politics now, but I sure did enjoy the Potterverse in its heyday. It was exciting waiting in line to buy the new books, and to go to see the first midnight showing of the movies.

I thought this was a pretty good puzzle for a Wednesday. 

Apparently, the emus didn't agree with my initial assessment. I TOOK A SHOT at a one-line comment, and got blocked, apparently. (When my second comment got approved, elsewhere, I took the hint.)
I would have solved this puzzle quicker if I hadn't been chased by a rogue bludger. It nearly knocked me off my broom!

The cross between an American make and model of car and a Saturday Night Live person was a Brit-stopper. And the cross between the unfamiliar FLIER spelling and an unknown (to me) soccer player was the coup de grace.
Otherwise, a pleasant solve, despite the theme being some sort of imaginary game---fortunately it wasn't essential to know anything about it.

Off topic/not off topic:

In today‚Äôs Squeezy puzzle, I learned a new word: 
rootle (v) to root (around). 
I‚Äôm providing that ‚Äúdefinition‚Äù based only on my reading, which suggests it is chiefly British. How about it, readers from the UK and elsewhere - Have you heard it? Used it?
I was so excited when I got to the revealer! What a treat, indeed. :)

Not a Harry Potter fan, so a meh puzzle for a Wednesday. Just as a million others mention, FLIER? No! No! No! 
Solved it, but took me longer than usual, after losing steam after detecting theme.
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=ms2Dr7Fw6qQ&pp=ygUZY29wbGFuZCBpIGJvdWdodCBtZSBhIGNhdA%3D%3D Evidently, he never bought him a goat.

I know it doesn't actually make sense in any which way but my heart still wanted 18D to be NEWT. The heart wants what it wants. 

This was fun, fast, and smooth‚Äîlike a good mug of butterbeer. 

Liked the clue for GEL a lot. 

No idea why a signature Caitlin Clark shot is THREE (or who she is), so I better go look that up now.

I am a long time Jeopardy fan, and I was surprised that no one else caught this. The contestants come up with the questions. Alex Trebek reads the answers. This isn't just a niggling complaint. It's integral to the game. Great puzzle, though. (I was able to finish up quickly when I reread the clue that I thought was "Publicly" hound.)
WORLDBEATER?  Really?  Ew.  I really hoped it was WORLDBESTER but alas, this threw me off in more way than one. MEH indeed.

I haven‚Äôt read Harry Potter but of course I know of the books with their enormous success and their revered author.  I have also seen some of her tweets  where she traded barbs and insults with other posters on topics that she cared about. I respect her views and actually don‚Äôt disagree with some of them, but that kind of publicity makes her less of a great person in my regard. It takes away the mysterious aura that some other great writers, like J. D. Salinger or Harper Lee, have. Sometimes less publicity is more.
What does the cow/sheep hybrid say? MAA!

Alas, Harry Potter forever tainted by the author being the cheerleader-in-chief for stoking anti-trans hysteria (perhaps second only to the future commander-in-chief). At least solving this didn‚Äôt put any more money in her pockets.
today actually felt a bit more like a saturday puzzle
I loved this theme-- it made for a quick easy Tuesday, but I got snagged at MAA and ROE. Wouldn't it be BAA and DOE, respectively?
Most hoop junkies, would refer to Caitlin's signature shot as a TREY.
"I'll  take Let it Snow for 800, Alex."

I was rootling around through the comments below, and saw people were not happy with "flier."

I don't spell so good, so for some words I always consider that I may have a letter or two wrong.

For example, "dryer," which I think is the correct spelling. I usually wonder whether it is drier or dryer and let the cross set me straight.

So my lack of knowledge was once again a benefit here at the crosswords.

I'd make a joke about ignorance and bliss, but I suspect a number of commenters here would be upset given our current situation, so I will refrain.

Fun puzzle, but MAA? Can we make a rule no more "barnyard sounds" as clues? Too many variants for writing out the sound numerous possible animals make. I, like I'm sure many others, put in BAA initially.

A tennis line judge has bever said "it's in". A horrible first clue especially when the only thing a tennis line judge does actually say, "fault", is also 5 letters. MAA and AHAS are the worst type of answer. Also personally hated the harry potter theme but that one's subjective

3D was a trigger for me.

Everyone I know LOVES sweet potatoes.  

I cannot stand them.  Can't stand them baked, mashed, in a casserole, or as fries.

I don't think there's any other food I find more disgusting than sweet potatoes.  I don't know why.
There's a fly in this puzzle's ointment. Otherwise, not too BAAd.

@Steve L

I didn‚Äôt feel too tough, but my time ended up being way higher than my recent average. Nice change of pace.

@Steve L 

My time was about half of last week's and still longer than a usual Tuesday for me.

@Steve L I had a different experience‚Äîmy time was well below my average Tuesday time today. But I benefited from the Harry Potter theme, which gave me the answers to the spanners very quickly. Will be interested to see how others find this puzzle!
@Rachel for me it came in a little faster than average, but felt easier. I was not familiar with the phrase ‚Äúworld beater‚Äù, so the HP theme definitely helped me.
@Steve L I thought last week‚Äôs Tuesday was easier than last Monday‚Äôs and sort of felt the same today. However, my time was faster than my average

@Steve L 

This took 60% of the time I needed last week, and felt Tuesday-ish, unlike that infamous grid.

@Steve L 

I thought this was quite easy and just right for Tuesday.  I don't keep time but I probably finished a lot faster than normal.

This had a decent theme but it was nothing like the difficulty (or cleverness) of last Tuesday.  In my estimation.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@Steve L scant seconds longer than my Tuesday average.
@SP This is not a suitable forum for our hate. Sorry to disappoint.
@SP Who is JK Rowland?

@SP I am opposed to all cultural flotsam in these puzzles (e.g. HP, Star Wars, one-hit TV/ music/rap wonders) but in particular those that give recognition to those who marginalize groups of well-meaning fellow brothers and sisters (so I would include e.g. Roald Dahl as well).
@RIch Garella Why hate at all?
My portmanteau pleasure!
@Justin hello neighbor. While your references have lost me tonight, my answer is yes.

@Justin 

Buck
.
.
.
.
. 
Futter

@Megan

I went down a Trebeck SNL rabbit hole, myself. Thank you for playing. üê¥
Megan, To be sure. https://merriam-webster.com/dictionary/world-beater

@L.S.

The AP Stylebook would agree with you. ‚ÄúTaking a flier‚Äù for the Associated Press means ‚Äúto take a big risk.‚Äù Not a handbill.
It may "usually" be a Y for this meaning, but the I is also accepted, and most solvers would be expected to know how to spell [Hamm of soccer fame]. https://merriam-webster.com/dictionary/flier

@Sara perhaps oddly, and certainly to my amusement, farmers or crossword constructors or both seem to have decided that goats say MAA while sheep say BAA. I have spent a bit of time around both species and whenever this comes up I try to recall whether there was a noticeable difference in their sounds that might be particularly well represented by the B vs. M distinction. So far, I haven't straightened it out in my brain, but I accept it as true for puzzling purposes!
@Sara I completely agree Sara. Ridiculous.

@Steven M. 

Sometimes line judges think out loud.
@Bill in Yokohama I don't think so. Figure skating and Gymnastics would be higher

@dutchiris Maybe, but unless the ball was was a clean winner, if a judge ever said "it's in," the umpire would immediately call a let, and the point would be replayed. It's also possible the judge would be removed from the tournament

@Steven M. 

The clue is [Ruling from a tennis line judge]. It doesn‚Äôt say anything about a call made during play. This ‚Äúruling‚Äù might be made during a ‚Äúdiscussion‚Äù (think McEnroe) after the ball goes by the complaining player.

@Steven M. 

Yes, as calculated on the basis of how many competitors are participating at a given time. But the panel of skating or gymnastics judges judge all the participants at a competition, not just the one who is up at any given time.

@Steven M. I didn't like this clue either. I'd almost prefer it as "call from a rec tennis player" because it's something you'd say when making your own calls, not something a line judge at a tournament would say. 

I suppose possibly the chair umpire at Roland Garros might say it when inspecting the clay mark but not the line judge. Ah well, pedantic.

I would have preferred ITSIN clued to a statement from a tennis commentator,
but the clue does say "ruling," not "utterance," so IMO it's very awkward but not incorrect.

Hi @Bill in Yokohama This may have been true at one point, but now (at least at the major tournaments) line judges have been replaced with cameras and software that call all lines. So, now there are fewer people on court to call the match (1 chair umpire for 2 singles players) than playing.
@Barry Ancona So... I'm right to call it... "terrible cluing"

Steven M.,

If  you consider "very awkward but not incorrect" to be "terrible," go for it.
@Min -- " ... two three four, tell the people what she wore" ..
@Wark Board says: The 51st State for $1,000,000,000,000. Answer: What is the birthplace of Alex Trebek?

@Elizabeth Ross 
Just half its annual GDP to own it? Real ‚ÄúMexico will pay for it‚Äù vibes. Granted, for a guy who reportedly stiffs his contractors regularly, maybe that was your point.
@Nick It's a negotiation, no?
@Heidi Cricky and frunchy are so far top contenders!

@Heidi 

I'm a fan of - Frunchy!  No question on pronunciation.

I only saw the first HP movie.  It was in a live theater venue with the background music player by the RI Philharmonic Orchestra.  Great way to see a movie!

For some reason, I didn't enjoy it.  So, I never saw any more of them (nor read any of the books).  I do like the books she wrote under a male pen name (Robert Gilbraithe - I think).

I enjoyed the puzzle even though I didn't know the positions  noted in the themer.  

Frunchy!

@Heidi 

Totes adding

frunchy and 
cricky

to my vocabs.

Note to all- 
CC is lit.


At least in one way‚Ä¶

MRR,

Sports may not be your forte, 
but MIA Hamm is a fact, not trivia.

@Barry Ancona 
Is trivia not factual?

NH,

Fine. MIA Hamm is a non-trivial fact.

@Barry Ancona 

Could it be possible that all sports facts are trivial to MRR?
Even if you have managed to miss MIA Hamm IRL, she has appeared in the grid more than 25 times in the last decade. Neither the editors nor Rex Parker would think she was in Natick.

@Barry Ancona

I can see Mia Hamm being "sports trivia" to MRR versus, say, Babe Ruth or Pele. The clue for the soccer player appeared just once all last year. Whether it's trivia to her is just her feeling and not in need of challenging.

@Oikofuge I don't think FLIER is an "American spelling"; FLYER is the preferred spelling overall in English globally, https://tinyurl.com/5e36exnm and also the preferred British spelling, https://tinyurl.com/yrjfy26p as well as the preferred American spelling: https://tinyurl.com/33vmy8xx Both countries show about the same ratio, about 3:1 to 4:1 for FLYER. FLIER is just an alternate form of FLYER. Some sources say one is an aviator, and the other is a handout, but they apparently can't agree which is which. And of course, the rule is that it doesn't matter which is more accepted, as long as the less common version is accepted. On the other hand, a DRYER is a machine, and DRIER is "more dry". (I guess FLYER could be someone who is more fly, like someone who was more hep in the 20th [or was the the 19th?] century.)

@Barry Ancona I would consider the names of most athletes ‚Äútrivia‚Äù. Wasn‚Äôt trying to be controversial; just pointing out that I‚Äôm not especially knowledgeable about sports. I‚Äôm also not from the USA, as is made clear by the location listed when I post, so the names of foreign athletes are more obscure for me than what you might experience south of the border.

@MRR 

Likewise.
I'm sure Mia Hamm is a fine football player and human being, but as someone who has no interest in competitive sport generally, and soccer in particular, it seems to me that the name of a soccer player from another country is practically the definition of trivial knowledge, for me. 
I strongly suspect that I've never heard her name uttered, and if I had I would have had no reason to try to remember it, out of all the names I hear uttered in a day.
That doesn't say anything bad about her, or about me---it's just the inevitable consequence of a world full of facts, some of which are more useful than others.

@Oikofuge 

What I saw was that "flyer" was a handbill 100% of the time in British English, and about 70% of the time in American English.  

That doesn't make FLIER "the American spelling", but rather a variant in American English.

I also noticed that if you don't isolate for context, you'll find that many hits for FLIER are about aviators, not posters.

The takeaway here, I think, is that this American phenomenon isn't specific to handbills, and isn't the predominant form for either definition.  The only thing I can deduce from my research is that the Brits use it more for aviators than for pamphlets, and neither nation uses FLIER more than "flyer".

@MRR
MIA Hamm is hardly obscure. She is to women's soccer what Gretzky is to hockey, to put it in Canuck speak.

@Steve L 

"What I saw was that "flyer" was a handbill 100% of the time in British English, and about 70% of the time in American English."

Well, strictly, the word for a handbill was spelled "flyer" 100% of the time in BrE, and about 70% of the time in AmE. I wouldn't care to guess what proportion of the time "flyer" was used in British English to mean "handbill", as opposed to other meanings.

"That doesn't make FLIER "the American spelling", but rather a variant in American English."

Nor did I claim that FLIER was "the American spelling". I wrote that my take-home message was "the American spelling of FLIER". Because, in the context of a handbill, FLIER is an American spelling that is rare in British English. It is, at present, a distinctively American usage, even if rarer than FLYER.

I'm not sure why that triggered all the Ngrams---you seem to be arguing against something I didn't say.

@Times Rita 

I‚Äôm not sure you could really call the theme answers sports clues, given that QUIDDITCH is an invention of the author, and not an actual sport.

@Times Rita 
They're usually love tests because they're almost always amazing feats of construction. I think the Times only ends up accepting maybe one out of twenty entries, and only those after an extensive series of revisions. The New York Times crossword is pretty much the gold standard.

A puzzle you have difficulty with doesn't have to be unpleasant and frustrating. A lot of problem-solving involves backing away when nothing works and coming back to it later. It's why I don't worry about how long it takes me to solve a puzzle. At the very least, I move to a different section if I get stuck. Sometimes I'll just put it down and go do something else.

But above all else, a lot of it depends on your mental state. 

I'm two years into learning classical guitar, and I'm an old man. A lot of what's involved isn't just repetition; it's minute adjustments in hand position, finger pressure, posture, practice techniques...when things aren't working, you put it away for awhile. If you just can't solve it, you ask for help. But frustration and anger are something you allow yourself, and you can choose not to do that.
